abstract: United States District Court rules General Motors does not need  to hand over privileged documents to drivers in case relating to crash of three Chevrolet Cobalts; ruling comes despite probable cause that GM committed fraud by hiding defect from regulators and public; vehicle owners say deception justifies waiver of attorney-client privilege.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled that General Motors need not turn over documents to drivers who are hoping to show that it intended to commit fraud by concealing defective ignition switches.

headline.main: Judge’s Decision on Documents Favors G.M.
headline.print_headline: Judge’s Decision on Documents Favors G.M. and Its Lawyers
